Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Accelerated Growth of Hydroponic Lettuce for Greenhouse and Indoor Farmers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potnetial of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve hydroponic production of leafy greens. Growing food indoors hydroponically produces locally grown vegetables with minimal or no pesticide or herbicide use. A key challenge is the limitation on crop volume based on farm size. This project will advance a fertilizer that can grow an additional 10 to 20% more with current space and equipment. It will have an impact on global farming by increasing crop volume without environmental impact.

This SBIR Phase I project will explore translation of an innovative method for trisulfide production for use in fertilizers. Tasks include development of a simple, one-step synthesis of the fertilizer from inexpensive, commercially available starting materials. Further work includes investigation of synthesis parameters for development of a process at the 500 g scale, then further exploration of the parameter space for eventual industrial production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Theion Agriculture received an NSF SBIR award in Fall of 2020 to accelerate the growth of hydroponic lettuce. The indoor hydroponics market produces a variety of leafy greens that are grown in greenhouses with natural light or in buildings with artificial lighting. By growing leafy greens indoors and out of the elements, a high level of control over the environment to optimize important parameters such as lighting, humidity, carbon dioxide levels, and temperature to maximize the yield of leafy greens to enable companies to turn a profit. Indoor farmers face stiff competition from lettuce produced outdoors in California and Arizona where 98% of lettuce is produced through outdoor farming. Indoor farmers differentiate themselves by growing leafy greens that are locally grown without the use of pesticides and herbicides and are often delivered to stores the same day they are harvested. One of the main problems that indoor production faces is the high cost of energy required to grow crops year-round. The innovation that Theion Agriculture investigated was whether a special additive, that when added to the nutrient stream of the hydroponic system, would accelerate the growth of the leafy greens with no increase in the energy input of the system. This would allow farmers to increase their production by increasing their turns per year while maintaining a relatively stable energy cost.

Theion Agriculture used the funds to test a new additive formulated for hydroponic systems and to develop a synthesis to scale production of the additive. We set up our own hydroponic system in an indoor facility to test a several viable candidates for our additives. This allowed us to have complete control over the grow environment. Much of the synthetic work was done in conjunction with the University of Iowa. We developed a synthesis for our most viable candidate with a purity of 61.5%.

Unfortunately using the additives that we initially proposed did not produce the desired effect in our lettuce crops. We tried numerous varieties of lettuce, different amounts of nutrients, timing of the addition of our additive, making custom nutrients, changing the lighting, as well as trying various additive candidates to produce the desired increase in growth.

While the initial grant was funded to commercialize an additive to improve the growth of hydroponic leafy greens, we were unsuccessful to bring this product to market at this time. While we were not able to develop a commercial additive during the grant period, there is still an unmet need in the industry to increase yield for hydroponic leafy greens. While the focus in the industry has been lighting and automation, nutrients is still a field that needs improvement.
